comments.commentBody:
Hmmm interesting..... Papandreou hasn't listened to his people and now after pain staking promises to the EU to implement severe austerity measures, etc. and finally 'scoring' a deal he decides to let the people vote. A comment I saw on one other site pretty much sums it up:

"For cynical politicians – late in the day - to give the Greek People a “free choice” between decades of austerity and immediate financial collapse is rather like Henry VIII giving Anne Boleyn a “free choice” between a swordsman and an axeman for her execution!"

Well said.

I am so tired of hearing about Greece.  I think they should leave the EU, UN, and every other organization that is trying to help them.  They are so stubborn & selfish.  Let them try to make it on their own.  They can keep their comfy government jobs and their retirement at 40.  They can protest, have general strikes, and revolt until the cows come home, for all I care.  The EU tried to give them a good offer and then this.  The market hangs on their every action.  They say or do something stupid and the market falls. I do not want to hear any more about Greece.
Bravo Greece!  Let the banks and the investors take a hit.  Let them join the rest of down here at the bottom...working for nothing and shopping at the dollar stores.

Optimism, please ! The sky is not falling as some predict.

Papandreou has shrewdly realized he can can pressure Europe for a better deal.

Thus in the end there's a bigger haircut and Greece remains in the Euro.

Ditto for the others.

What a mess! Is it worse than the mess here? Conceivably. My family writes me from Czech Republic (NOT a Eurozone member) about the feelings the Czechs share with many Germans: enough is enough. The absurdity to put together Northern Europeans and Southern Europeans is now becoming a major crisis. Here it was somewhat (not completely) resolved during the Civil War with major residues still lingering.

What effect all of this nonsense will have on us? Hard to tell. Nothing good but is it going to be VERY bad or just bad. Let's hope for the latter...

The fact that we are not sure whether Ai Weiwei really owes a lot of taxes has everything to do with the way the Chinese government has handled the case.  If the officials do have documents showing Ai Weiwei's tax evasion, why didn't they provide copies of the documents to Ai Weiwei's attorneys?  If they indeed refused to share such documents with Ai's defense, as reported here, then the only likely explanation is that the officials were lying.  And would that be a surprise?  Officials anywhere in the world should be subject to a healthy dose of suspicion even in the best situations and the officials in China, sadly, are not generally known (at least not in recent historical times) for their integrity.

Too bad the effect of moderate alcohol consumption on the "average woman's" relative risk of heart disease wasn't also reported in this article.  But IIRC, for someone like me with no first degree relatives with breast cancer and two grandparents who died of heart disease, a drink a day is the way to go!  Meanwhile I'll keep my BMI under 20, eat low on the food chain, continue hiking and skiing daily, get plenty of sleep, pet my dog, hug my husband, opt out of TSA full body scans, get mammograms about every two years, and choose watchful waiting over CYA breast biopsies.  So far it's paying off . . .

The studies always seem to point to things we can control: alcohol, deodorant, fish oil, certain vitamins, exercise, aluminum pots, etc. Notice that the cause of disease, especially cancer, is never, ever attributed to untested chemicals in our food, water and air. Chems are in practically is everyone and we all know this, yet we don't know (or test) for an association with disease. Instead, we totter back and forth with what amounts to consumer warnings and only guess at the interplay between our genes and the enviroment.

It's unfortunate for Dr. Susan Love to say that there is a trade-off between breast cancer risk and cardiovascular disease risk, when it comes to alcohol.  There are many alternatives for reducing cardiovascular disease risk than drinking alcohol.  On the other hand, all cancer authorities, including the World Health Organization, have identified all forms of alcohol as a carcinogen.  (One criteria for being a carcinogen is that higher intake or exposure results in higher cancer risk.)  Researchers have known for years that alcohol can cause breast cancer, along with many other cancers.  While the focus of the low heart disease rates in France has been on the consumption of wine, few discussed the high breast cancer rates among males (in France).  Like other cancers, breast cancer affects both men and women.  Alcohol is a part of our society and is not going away.  If a person chooses to drink any form of alcohol, it would be a good strategy to keep the intake small and infrequent.  Additionally, a good strategy would include reducing other cancer risks, such as smoking, consuming, inhaling, or absorbing known carcinogens (check World Health Organization for list).  Disease risk reduction is a personal matter.  It would be nice if everyone could avoid cancer, heart disease, alzheimers, etc. throughout their lifetimes.  However, many people believe that bad things always happen to "the other guy".  Some people also never want to hear what can be considered as "bad news" and they need a reason to continue doing what they like. Cancer is the most expensive disease a person can get, given the cost of drugs and lengths of treatment.  It seems that family members should have some say in a person's lifestyle if it may lead to negative financial consequences at a future date?  Even the most lucrative pension may not be enough to pay for treatment if a person is lucky enough to live with cancer.  It can be gone in a number of months, even with insurance!

These studies are about as dumb as you can get. How can you possibly correct for the myriad of confounding social, environmental and genetic factors to possibly come to this conclusion? I'm sure one can find a link between orange juice and breast cancer if you look hard enough...

From the movie 'Sleeper'. Two doctors talking, both smoking cigarettes, if memory serves:

Dr. Melik: "You mean there was no deep fat? No steak or cream pies or... hot fudge?"

Dr. Aragon: "Those were thought to be unhealthy... precisely the opposite of what we now know to be true."
@24, Josh Hill:  You're being facetious, right?
When will the NYT stop writing about these ridiculous studies.  Correlation is not causation!

What was it George Carlin said? "Scientists have discovered that saliva gives you cancer, but only if swallowed in small quantities over a long period of time."

My maternal grandmother lived to 96. She had a healthy diet, was not obese, quite smoking at 55, and had a small glass of brandy after dinner every night. Her mother also lived to 96, had a healthy diet, was not obese, never smoked, and had a small glass of brandy after dinner every night, plus a glass of juice and an aspirin (Aha!) before going to bed.

My paternal grandmother lived to 98, had a healthy diet, was not obese, never smoked, and never had a drink in her life.

None of them spent a day in the hospital or ever had a mammogram or Pap smear. (A doctor tried to talk my grandmother into one when she was 90 and she laughed at him.)

Outside of really pushing the unhealthy lifestyle envelope to the extreme, genetics trumps all.

for those who think an absolute increase of 0.45% is meaningless - that means for every 1000 women in their 50s, 4 or 5 of them will get breast cancer from drinking 1/2-1 glass/day versus not.

women who find themselves in a higher risk group who ask for advice on what they can ACTIVELY do to prevent breast cancer --> drink less! - easier to control this (along with a healthy diet and exercise) than timing the onset of puberty, menopause, when to have your first child, your family history -->these are risk factors that are much harder to control on an individual basis.

judging from the comments though, it seems too many women don't want to hear this and perhaps enjoy their drinking a bit too much...

The election of Palestine to UNESCO membership is in violation of the UN rules as they are as yet not a country. This will further UNESCO's biased behavior. All countries who accept the UN rules should withdraw their support of UNESCO.

comments.commentTitle: Starts weak and goes downhill from there
comments.commentBody: The Coen piece is competant, but the May and Allen plays are extrordinarily badly written. May seems to have tried, but the results are pathetic. I can only think that Allen is deliberately expressing his contempt for his audience. What a disappointment!

comments.commentTitle: i guess i am showing my age
comments.commentBody: i didn't think i could be shocked or disgusted by anything in the theater, but this play did it.  If you think discussions of flatulence, constipation, masturbation, in connection with racism and hate sound like a fun evening in the theater, this show is for you.  And don't forget lot of simulated sex and nudity (of actors who you probably don't want to see nude).

comments.commentTitle: GODSPELL IS GOOD FOR THE SOUL
comments.commentBody: This show has held up so well particularly with some updating, current humor and a very talented cast.  The audience went nuts several times and the cast is clearly into what they're doing.  Godspell is good for the soul.

This was an insightful study of family coupled with a revelation at the end that leaves the viewer reassessing everything he has witnessed for the previous two hours.  it reverberates in all the right ways to have us reassess what it might mean to love, as a family member.  i saw the lincoln center production, and i think it holds up very well, but i do miss linda lavin, whose having quite a banner year with this originating a role in this production, being incredible in "follies" and in "the lyons."  by the way, there's something amiss with the rating system.  I wanted to give this a five star rating, but it automatically went on as a three star.

And the next study will say that two glasses of wine, one on Tues and one on Wed,  followed by consuming a bushel of broccoli every other Sunday will decrease the risk of breast cancer by .02%.  And it will be published. Statistical significance, arbitrarily set by scientists wanting to publish to further their careers needs to be reevaluated.

Next week:

"A Few Drinks a Week LOWERS Breast Cancer Risk."

Live life. Enjoy.

Too big to fail = Too big to exist.

Continue to buy off my representatives in Congress. At some point, we the people will be heard.

There's something here that makes me really angry.

Every single in vitro study that's been published on marijuana and breast cancer since 1974 has found that the active ingredients in marijuana are able to kill breast cancer cells without harming normal tissue.

So do pot smokers get more breast cancer than average, or less?

Based on the in vitro data, it seems like the answer should be: marijuana users get less breast cancer than average.

So why haven't any population studies been done in order to complete this picture?

Are scientists so afraid of the answer that they've decided the question is better left unasked?

After all, that would start a huge controversy in our society, if it turned out that smoking pot prevented breast cancer while alcohol, the legal alternative, caused it.
Seriously, what did folks expect Bank of America to do in response to the waves of outrage? This was PR tap dancing, nothing more.
